title: Magnetic flux - doubling variables to affect flux

content.question: A square loop with sides of length <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math> is inclined at an angle <math alttext="theta equals 45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn><mo>°</mo></math> above the horizontal. A magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> points horizontally to the right passing through the loop, as shown. A single quantity can be changed in the scenario. If only the magnitude of the magnetic field is doubled, the magnetic flux is <math alttext="phi sub 2 B, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></math>. If only the side length is doubled, the magnetic flux is <math alttext="phi sub 2 s, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></math>. If only the angle is doubled, the magnetic flux is <math alttext="phi sub 2 theta, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly compares the magnitude of the flux through the loop for each of the three changes?

choices.label: <math alttext="phi sub 2 theta, end sub, is greater than phi sub 2 B, end sub, which equals phi sub 2 s, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="phi sub 2 s, end sub, is greater than phi sub 2 B, end sub, which is greater than phi sub 2 theta, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="phi sub 2 B, end sub, equals phi sub 2 s, end sub, which is greater than phi sub 2 theta, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="phi sub 2 B, end sub, equals phi sub 2 theta, end sub, which equals phi sub 2 s, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="phi sub 2 s, end sub, is greater than phi sub 2 B, end sub, which is greater than phi sub 2 theta, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
